awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Multi-scale movement behavior in primates
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

 Movement is a fundamental aspect of primate life, as it is key to survival, reproduction, adaptation, and evolution. At fine scales, movement affects individual survival and reproduction through its role in foraging behavior, predator avoidance, and mate acquisition, while larger scale movement can influence local adaptations and speciation via its role in dispersal, population connectivity, and gene flow. This doctoral dissertation project investigates how fine and large-scale movement decisions in primates reflect spatial and temporal variability in their environment. The research provides important insight regarding human land use and its effects on primate movement, providing local reforestation practitioners key information to help direct their conservation efforts. Moreover, the project strengthens research infrastructure and contributes to the education and training of students, including individuals from groups underrepresented in STEM, and the general public. 

To evaluate environmental impacts on ruffed lemur multiscale movement, this project has two main objectives: (1) to assess how fine-scale movement varies through time and along an ecological disturbance gradient at four research sites; and (2) to examine how historic and contemporary environmental variation in the broader region explains large-scale movement and dispersal in the species. The investigators quantify fine-scale environmental differences across the disturbance gradient by using botanical surveys, monitoring monthly food availability, and assessing three- dimensional forest structure with drones. Investigators track lemur movement at each site with GPS collars; this information lets investigators identify aspects of forest structure (e.g., tree canopy cover and connectivity) that influence lemur habitat use. Large-scale landcover, land change, and forest structure is quantified with botanical surveys and classification of satellite images. The investigators use population genetic assessments to quantify lemur dispersal patterns throughout the region, followed by landscape genetic techniques to identify which environmental variables drive dispersal patterns in this species. Overall, this project clarifies how environmental variation and habitat change have influenced and continue to influence fine- and large-scale lemur movement and habitat use. Therefore, the insights derived from this project provide foundational information by which to evaluate environmental drivers of primate evolution at multiple levels.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The environment plays a central role in whether, when, where, and how often a primate moves throughout its habitat, and can have direct implications for the genetic health, diversity and structure of individuals across landscapes. Nevertheless, few primate studies have addressed how individual movement decisions are influenced by environmental variation, and whether these decisions vary across space and time. This project investigated movement in black-and-white ruffed lemurs (Varecia variegata), within the context of environmental variation across multiple spatial and temporal scales. Using a landscape genetics approach, we found that short-range ruffed lemur dispersal (i.e., dispersal within a constrained region of the COFAV rainforest corridor of southeastern Madagascar) was best explained by terrain ruggedness and canopy height encountered between-sites, suggesting that ruffed lemurs disperse through the least rugged terrain that enables them to remain within their preferred tall-canopied forest habitat. Moreover, gravity models revealed that forest productivity metrics, including the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) – a measure of within-site vegetation density – and the average Importance Value Index (IVI) of ruffed lemur food trees, were the most influential within-site drivers of ruffed lemur dispersal, with animals being more likely to disperse into areas with lower NDVI and higher IVI values. Surprisingly, when between- and within-site drivers were combined, models containing only between-site resistances were consistently the best supported. We therefore conclude that the within-site environmental variables tested were less influential in ruffed lemur dispersal decisions than between-site factors. Together, when combined with our earlier work, these results suggest scale-dependent environmental effects on ruffed lemur dispersal and movement: short-range dispersal decisions appear to be motivated by forest structure and quality, whereas longer-range ruffed lemur dispersal (i.e., gene flow throughout the entire eastern rainforest corridor) is driven primarily by the presence of forest and proximity to human settlements. This research has resulted in the following tangible products: one doctoral dissertation, one published peer-reviewed scientific journal article, a second scientific journal article currently under review, and two additional scientific journal articles that are currently in preparation. Further, funding from this project allowed us to establish and maintain long-term phenological monitoring transects at four sites along a disturbance gradient in Ranomafana National Park; these transects are currently maintained and monitored by the Ranomafana Ruffed Lemur Project. Finally, this research supported the following training opportunities: a GIS workshop offered to staff and students at Centre ValBio Research Station (Madagascar); hands-on training in field data collection methods to three Malagasy graduate students; hands-on training internships in laboratory molecular genetic methods to four American undergraduate students at Hunter College; and hands-on training in remote sensing and analyzing GPS ranging data to one undergradate student as part of their undergraduate honors thesis.
